Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with this course compared to others you have taken was
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
How would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other F&ES courses you have taken?
Given the course objectives, the level of intellectual challenge of the material covered was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
How well did the knowledge, skills, and insights gained in this class align with your expectations
What are the strengths and weaknesses of the course and how could it be improved?
What advice would you give to a student considering taking this class
Comments_List: I gained a more in-depth understanding of forest succession and of various topics from pruning to forest carbon sequestration. One insight that will definitely stick with me is the ambiguity of forests' effects on climate.

The course gave me a soid understanding of the four phases of stand dynamics and a good overview of other concepts in forest dynamics. I appreciated the management insights, even though they were not the focus of the course. I also appreciated that Covey brought in new waves of thought.

I was able to get what I wanted from this class, which, as a non-MF student was really just an understanding of how forests work and develop over time. My goal was to apply this to my policy-oriented work, which, because of the final paper I was able to do.

This course was a valuable survey course introduction to forestry and trees for me. I knew very little about trees or forests when I started this course, and I learned a tremendous amount about, ranging from the large-scale dynamics of forests over time to forestry research methods to the basics of plant physiology.
I gained a foundational understanding of stand dynamics that will allow me to use the topics covered in this course as I move through the rest of my career as a forester and forested land manager.
I learned about the importance of forest management and about how forests develop.

I developed an understanding of how forests, whether at the stand or landscape level, function. Prior to this class, a forest was a forest. I can now see the forest as a progressive community of plants, moving through time and space. For me, this class elucidated the science of forestry.

Comprehensive overview of basic forest processes, discussion of how these differ by climate and latitude, basic tree physiology and breakdown of fundamental differences between gymnosperms and angiosperms, questioning my blind acceptance of paradigm that trees sequester carbon, philosophical discussions about value of wilderness/old growth.  Also strong course community, and really enjoyable trip to Great Mountain.
I developed a vocabulary for talking about forest structure and dynamics, and a knowledge of the major themes and historical trends in understanding forest ecology.

I gained a lot of knowledge about the four phases of stand development outlined by Chad Oliver.  I learned about some of the controversies surrounding these stages and how they can impact different aspects of society.
Forests grow in predictable patterns.
Basic knowledge of how forests work
This was exactly the course I was looking for: a broad approach to forests and tree dynamics with enough attention to detail that I felt knowledgeable but not overwhelmed.
An understanding of the forest stand dynamic paradigm.
I developed a better sense for academic reading and a general understanding of forest stand dynamics.
An in depth knowledge of the topics covered.
Reasonably well. Some parts of the course seemed fairly random and difficult to really learn in lecture form, like forest inventory and tree pruning. But the rest aligned well.
I thought that we'd have more ecology, but we focused a lot on trees. While I'm all for tree stuff, I would have liked more content on ecosystems.

Largely in line with what I wanted. I think the paper was really instrumental for me because I wanted to have some freedom to take what I wanted to learn from the course and apply it in a way that made sense for my own work.
My goal in taking the course was to get a solid introduction to forests and how forests change over time. In this way, the course met my expectations.

I learned a lot about what I expected to learn in this course. I also learned about many topics (urban street tree pruning, BVOC's, global carbon budgets, tree methane emissions) that I did not expect to be covered in stand dynamics.

For long sections of the semester I thought that I had learned little about forest dynamics but by taking the final exam I realized that my understanding of forest dynamics was much better than I had previously thought.
Fairly well. I developed a good understanding of the concepts of stand dynamics as set forth in the Oliver & Larson text.
I expected to learn more about the dynamics of a stand and not only mainly on the 4 stages.
Met expectations.
The class material was often presented in a not-very-organized way, and I was left feeling like I did not gain as much from the class as I thought I would.

I got about half of the knowledge, skills, and insights that I expected from this class.  I am pleased with my understanding of Oliver's stages of development and old growth issues.  The rest of the course was irrelevant.

Not great. I expected the course to be an introduction to all things forestry, and to be designed to accommodate both beginners and more advanced students. The material was covered in such a way that it was difficult for a beginner to launch into it and learn effectively.

Not well.  I had high hopes for this course as it was touted as a "cornerstone" of yale forestry and "fundamental" to my degree.  Instead, it was a very poor course overall and I'm quite upset at how much I had to pay to attend. You might need to consider a money-back policy for this course.
I hoped to learn more hard skills, and less of the theory.
Not very well, but well enough.  There were challenges.  The course was not as linear and easy follow as one would expect.
The course did not meet my expectations. I am disappointed with the lack of emphasis on forest stand dynamics.
By the end of the course, my expectations were met.

Strengths: engaging lectures, reasonably clear expectations and material, fun and informative field trip
Weaknesses: some stumbles with organization (totally understood that this is a transitional year for the course), less coherence of information post-midterm. But the biggest, most consistent weakness was probably the discussion portion of the course, which I think doesn't fit the course material and structure well. I could see some other participatory segment with a different approach working well instead.

Strengths: Covey is the best field lecturer out there. He also has a great sense of humor, and he was making a solid effort to keep the course informative, engaging, and relevant for students. 

Weaknesses: The syllabus and course organization. We had things moving around every which way such that it was impossible to tell what was going to happen in the course. Covey tended to get waylaid with tangential discussions during lecture. Also, the discussion sections were occasionally really interesting but usually not. I think that the conceptual readings were more interesting then the dense scientific papers. I really liked when Covey explained why the papers were important to the field. With practice and more work, I think the course will be more coherent in the future.

The classes and lectures were good, but the class was really unorganized throughout the semester. The syllabus changed no fewer than four times along with deliverables and field trip dates. I'm not sure why this was the case, but moving forward the class really need to have a bit more structure as I felt always unsure of what was due when and for what reason. The final exam was a perfect example - half of the class - including the TA - was unclear where the exam was taking place. A simple email, rather than an off-hand comment in class, would go a long way in providing the structure the course needs.

Kris' entusiasm and expertise made this class both informative and inspiring for me. The trip to Great Mountain was a highlight. I found being in the field extremely helpful in finally understanding the concepts we learned in the classroom. In future years, I would recommend going on more field trips and making the field component of the education a priority as I think it is hard to replicate in the classroom. The main weakness of this course was the organization at times. The course is ambitious in the topics that it covers, which is good, but sometimes as we jumped from one topic to another with dense research papers, I felt like I was losing the "forest through the trees," so to speak.

This course teaches core material that is essential to any student interested in a career in forestry. I would recommend spending more time covering the various phases of stand dynamics, and less time teaching students about the aforementioned topics that are tangentially related to stand dynamics, but are interesting nonetheless.

Strengths:

-Interesting content
-The great mountain field trip was exceptional

Weaknesses:
-Structure of the course
-Lecture slides
-Assignments

The strength of the class is that it conveys numerous topics that involve and implicate stand dynamics beyond the traditional teaching of this course. For future forest managers, this information is vital to decisionmaking, and discussing how to balance competing forest uses with potential landscape (global?) scale environmental impacts was a significant strength of the course.

However, the course could benefit from some additional organization. If BVOCs, Albedo, and GHGs are going to be included in the course going forward (as they should), it may be worth moving these lectures up to when tree physiology is discussed in the beginning of the class. Then, lectures can incorporate these aspects when appropriate.

Strengths: humor, discussion, GMF trip, methane lecture.
Weaknesses: It seems like we were working hard to complicate the 4 stanges of stand development which served little purpose.  I don't think there needed to be 5 lectures for that.  Its simple: Initiation- open growing space; exclusion- growing space is filled- competition induced mortality; understory reinitiation- holes in canopy (caused by a non-catastrophic disturbance) that cannot be assumed by existing canopy filled by new cohort; old-growth-  new cohort.  And then of course mentions of structure/biodiversity/etc.  I think also, the difference between catastrophic disturbance (sets stand back to initiation) vs non-catastrophic (i.e. gap dynamics) needs to be stresses, and the definition of "stand" needs to be stressed as relative.  The definition of stand is so broad it seems to hold zero objective meaning.

I recognize that this is a difficult class to teach, but it felt very scattered and disjointed. It was often hard to conceptualize the material, and maybe some things would have been better in a different order. It also would have been helpful to have more time in the field; I thought our trip to Great Mountain was one of the best parts of the class in terms of actually seeing and visualizing what we'd been talking about. We often did not do enough to connect the readings with the lecture material, and the lectures themselves sometimes felt lacking in detail.

The focus on Oliver's four stages of forest development is essential and was well executed in this course.  Likewise with old growth issues.  The weaknesses are plentiful.  The course was horribly organized: assignments were never clear and constantly changed, lectures (other than the four stages of stand development) came out of nowhere and rarely had any relation to each other or the course, and the discussions were impossible to prepare for and never made much sense.  The lack of structure and clarity throughout the semester made this course impossible to follow.
Too many papers to be effectively discussed in the allotted times; very theoretical and not a lot of applications/case studies discussed

The class jumped in to a lot of advanced and difficult topics quickly and not very methodically, and then jumped around between topics quickly. I was very confused for much of the course. I think this class should be a lot more elementary in nature, and really cover the basics of forest dynamics before jumping into "exciting" or philosophical topics. 
I wish this class had a more frequent lab component, so that we could see what were talking about in real life. I also think that "discussions" should be eliminated from the syllabus, or at least relegated to one discussion for the whole semester, since none of us knew what we were talking about and just BS-ed our way through the discussions.

The lectures were an obvious weak point and could clearly be improved upon if the professor spent more time preparing them.  This point was made very clear when comparing Covey's lectures against lecture slides from the previous year--especially because students who did well on the midterm were the ones who had access to these slides.

It is an interesting survey course for anyone who is planning to become acquainted with how forests work. 

A better organization and curation of readings and lecture slides could be greatly helpful to make this class accessible to any student  without forestry background. The reading load is little too much given the class meets twice a week.

I felt like we stayed mostly on track with the material, but definitely lacked a bit on the field trip and pset side of things.  The one pset we did I found immensely helpful for applying the information, and I think I would have benefited from two or three more psets of similar length and demand, so as to process the information.  

I wasn't able to go on the overnight field trip, and I felt that since the other trips didn't work out, I was missing some of that crucial field application.  Some better coordination on that front would've been nice.  

The main thing that I want to say here is that this was actually one of my favorite courses I've ever taken, not necessarily because of the information itself, but because of the volume of information.  I so often feel that classes have so much material to offer that I just cram and cram for the sake of the course and grade; this class had arguably less volume of material than some others, but it allowed me to really learn and understand it and feel fulfilled in the end.  And I don't necessarily mean to say that there was simply less material, but rather a healthy balance between the broader topics and their details that made everything into a more coherent whole than I've experienced elsewhere.  The presentation style and the grouping of the readings/discussions really worked for me.

The strengths of the course were the students. I felt as though I learned a lot just by engaging with them in private study groups. 

The heavy focus/ reliance on Chad's book was a weakness. I would have like to have learned the course from a practitioners experience. I wanted to learn some hard skills like: in quantifying timber in stands, or how to inventory. This felt glazed over. The course felt more like trees 101 rather than stand dynamics. 

I think the lecture slides could be improved:

- Less random imagery
- Reference links / citations 

When I went to use the slides to study, I realized just how many were just odd pictures used a lecture props. They were not helpful. I think the lecturer failed to recognize the importance of informational slides from the student's perspective. Rather, they felt more like prompts that support a lecture from a  keynote speaker or something. Visual reminders to say stuff. 

The TA was not integral to the course. She was very quiet, didn't share much. She held two study sessions for the final that were completely unstructured and useless. It would be great to have leveraged her experience and knowledge more. When she did speak, she seemed to know a lot. But, she rarely engaged with the class.
Strengths were a basic understanding of the principles of stand dynamics.  Weaknesses were the lack of field work and pointed linear progression of the syllabus.

The strengths of this course were the material covered and my interest in learning these topics. 

The weakness was in the copious amounts of reading, for which it was unclear what was most relevant and important.

I would say that if this is the one course you'll take on forests or trees, you may want to choose a different one. But it's a fairly good survey of forest succession and some other topics like forest carbon sequestration. Kris is an engaging professor, and while he certainly got on some folks' nerves, I value that portion of a professor's job pretty highly. He's also pretty honest about his experience and thoughts on forestry. The field trip is a lot of fun.
This has the potential to be a really great class, once Covey works out the kinks. In the interim, take everything on the syllabus with a grain of salt.

To be honest, the reading load was far too much and really on par with a law course more than a forestry class. It almost felt as though this was a seminar class, but with the addition of lectures, exams, problem sets and a paper. Because of that, really think about what you need to glean from from required readings and prioritize your work accordingly.

I really enjoyed this class and am glad I took it. This course was a valuable survey course introduction to forestry and trees for me. I knew very little about trees or forests when I started this course, and I learned a tremendous amount about, ranging from the large-scale dynamics of forests over time to forestry research methods to the basics of plant physiology. I think the course is also important for establishing a friendly community of first-year MFs.

If the course is being taught by Dr. Covey, expect to be responsible for teaching yourself much of the material. This is enjoyable if you are interested in the subject matter (i.e., an aspiring MF), but it is a waste of time and energy if you are an MEM simply interested in taking one class related to forests during your time here.

Otherwise, enjoy the material, this is a really fascinating subject matter and may change the way that you look at forests. The readings are engaging, and doing them will add to your experience in the course, even if you are just skimming, certainly look at them.
If you are interested in forest management take the class.
Take it!
I would discourage them, since this was not a great course for me. I felt I learnt little and was mostly confused.
Be selective about the readings you choose to do.  (skip right to the takeaway!)

I'm not a religious person, but I pray that when you are considering taking this class, it is nothing like it was in the fall of 2017.  If it does bear any resemblance to that pitiful semester, don't take it, just read "Forest Stand Dynamics" by Chad Oliver and Bruce Larson and "The Trouble With Wilderness" by William Cronon, you'll learn everything you need to know and save yourself a ton of money, headache, and frustration.
Don't take the course if Covey is teaching it and if he is, find the previous year's slides as soon as you can.
Good class if you have a forestry background, little too challenging if not.

If you love trees, this is absolutely the course for you. If you love forests, this is the course for you. If you love being outside or even just talking about being outside, this is the course for you.
Chads book covers most of the course material. You can learn most of the material just by reading the book.
I would encourage the student to engage more with the Oliver and Larson text than the lecture material.
